The treatise states:
Within these two verses there are eight topics.
What are the eight?

First, the gate of revealing the sovereign of the middle way; second, the gate of revealing the rules of the road; third, the gate of revealing the separation from mixture and unity; fourth, the gate of revealing the boundless hair-like growth; fifth, the gate of revealing the various separations from consciousness; sixth, the gate of revealing the unreality of the provisional existence; seventh, the gate of revealing the non-existent affairs; eighth, the gate of revealing the complete unobstructedness. These are called the eight.
Within the gate of revealing the sovereign of the middle way, there are five kinds.
What are the five?

First, the sovereign of the responsive body that accords with and transforms; second, the sovereign of the transforming body that is unobstructed by existence and non-existence; third, the sovereign of the Dharma body that is the fundamental substance and nature; fourth, the sovereign of the complete path where the fundamental and the branches are both severed; fifth, the sovereign that naturally accords with and responds without obstruction. These are called the five.
In the Sutra of the Great Dharani of Cultivating the Causes of Practice, it is said:
At that time, the Flower Wheel Treasure Light Celestial Son then addressed the Buddha, saying:
'World-Honored One!
How many are the number of the foremost guides that can be conceived of or not conceived of?

I only pray that the World-Honored One will open and reveal it for us, so that our great assembly, hearing their names, will always recite and always contemplate them, leaving the store of ignorance and reaching the city of nirvana.'
Thereupon, the World-Honored One told the celestial son:
'If I were to speak their names with my supernormal powers for immeasurable, limitless asaá¹ƒkhyeya eons, I still would not be able to finish.
I will now speak briefly, proclaiming their essentials for you and the others.
Good man!
The number of the enlightened ones is vast, perfect, and surpasses the sands of the Ganges, briefly explained as five kinds.
What are the five?

First, the Buddha of following substance; second, the Buddha of transformed substance; third, the Buddha of the substance of phenomena; fourth, the Buddha of the incomprehensible; fifth, the Buddha of responding transformation.'
And so on, it is explained in detail.
As stated in the verse: I pay homage to all the illuminating ones without exception.
For what meaning is it that all guides are called masters?
For three meanings.
What are the three?
First, the meaning of self-mastery, because they are Dharma kings;
Second, the meaning of being at the summit, because they are the only ones in the three realms;
Third, the meaning of being all-pervading, because there is nowhere they do not reach.
These are the three.
Thus far, the gate of revealing the master in the middle has been explained. Next, the gate of revealing the rules of the road will be explained.
In this gate, there are six kinds.
What are the six?

First, the principle of unimpeded and sovereign guidance through the navel of sound; second, the principle of the single, originally pure and equal ground, free from all falsehood; third, the principle of the power of each and every adornment of growth; fourth, the principle of the complete perfection of the ultimate, all-encompassing; fifth, the principle of no name, no form, no substance, no function, no creation, no action; sixth, the principle of the natural, ever-present, unchanging, ineffable, ultimate, pure perfection. These are called the six.
In the Sutra of the Adamantine SamÄdhi, Unimpeded Liberation, the Real Nature of the Fundamental Wisdom, it is said:
Moreover, MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!
If I were to explain extensively, there would be a total of ten billion, seventy thousand, three hundred and fifty Dharma gates for practitioners to traverse;
If I were to explain concisely, there would be a total of six principles for practitioners to traverse.
These six principles comprehensively encompass the ocean of all immeasurable and boundless principles.
What are the six?

First, the principle of speaking; second, the principle of equality; third, the principle of types; fourth, the principle of superiority; fifth, the principle of non-principle; sixth, the principle of permanence.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
As a verse says: Not one, not one, the principle of all dharmas.
For what meaning are all the Dharma treasures called principles?
For three meanings.
What are the three?
First, the meaning of a golden seal; the Dharma gate is always unchanging, like that seal;
second, the meaning of leading; guiding practitioners to enter the path, like that guide;
third, the meaning of being able to uphold; well upholding one's own characteristics without losing them, like that upholder.
These are the three.
Thus far, the gate of displaying the principles of the road has been explained. Next, the gate of displaying the separation from mixture and unification will be explained.
In this gate, there are three kinds.
What are the three?

First, the bound are combined into one. All immeasurable, boundless, and innumerable classes of afflictions and ignorance are reborn. Although there is no internal combination into one, there is external combination into one, because the meaning of unity is established by means such as quantity.

Second, the liberated are combined into one. All immeasurable, boundless, and innumerable sages of the three vehicles, etc., have internally the meaning of a combined unity, and externally the meaning of a combined unity that is the same as the dust.

Third, those who are both complete and neither are combined into one. All immeasurable, boundless, and innumerable great sages in the adamantine middle, etc., have both the meaning of the two, that which is able to accord and that which is accorded.
These are called the three.
In the Sutra of MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«'s Supreme and Inexhaustible Debate, it is said:
Although the ocean of the saá¹…gha is immeasurable, its fundamental essence is only of three kinds.
What are the three?
First, the ground of non-disputation without basis; second, the ground of non-disputation with both [basis and non-basis]; third, the ground of non-disputation with basis.
... and so on, explaining in detail.
Therefore, in the verse it says not counting, not thinking, immeasurable, and one.
For what meaning is it that all the Saá¹…gha are called combined into one?
Because there are two meanings.
What are the two?
First, the meaning of accumulation, gathering immeasurable and boundless scattered dust;
second, the meaning of one kind, peacefully stopping immeasurable and boundless waves of consciousness.
These are called the two.
Thus far, the approach of revealing separation from mixture and combining into one has been explained. Next, the approach of revealing boundless hair growth will be discussed.
In this approach, there are three approaches.
What are the three?

First, the boundless approach of hair growth with type; second, the boundless approach of hair growth with emptiness; third, the boundless approach of hair growth with resemblance. These are called the three.
In the first category, there are four types.
What are the four?
First, oviparous birth; second, viviparous birth; third, moisture-born birth; fourth, spontaneous birth. These are called the four.
These four kinds of birth can encompass all the immeasurable classes of beings, the fundamental names and numbers.
In the second category, there are three types.
What are the three?
First, the class of empty space hidden in light; second, the class of empty space hidden in dark colors; third, the class of empty space hidden in wind and clouds. These are called the three.
These three classes are empty because of emptiness, because of concealment.
One should carefully observe the retinue of empty classes, their number is numerous but does not exceed this measure.
In the third category, there are also three types.
What are the three?

First, the similarity of illusory transformations and magical spells, where the characteristics are unreasonable; second, the similarity of transformed medicines and talismans, where the characteristics are unreasonable; third, the similarity of following the original and manifesting images, this is called the three.
These three categories can subsume all the immeasurable and boundless various kinds of similarities, and the names and numbers of the fundamental [dharmas].
In the Sutra of the Dharma Gates of Collecting Categories, it is said:
There are ten kinds of consciousnesses, broadly speaking, and three kinds, briefly speaking.
What are the three?

First, the consciousness of sentient beings who are close to existence; second, the consciousness of sentient beings who hide in places and are unseen; third, the consciousness of sentient beings who seem to move and change from afar, these are called the three.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Therefore, in the verse, it says and the various kinds of beings in the realms of existence.
For what meaning are all sentient beings called hairy beings?
Because there are two meanings.
What are the two?
First, the meaning of indefinite movement, because there is no fixed dharma in following the destinies to receive birth;
Second, the meaning of many and innumerable, because the sides and corners have no quantity.
These are called the two.
In this gate, it is shown that sages are like horns, which are few, and ordinary beings are like hairs, which are many.
Thus far, the gate of manifesting boundless hair growth has been explained. Next, the gate of manifesting various distinctions from consciousness will be explained.
In this gate, there are two kinds.
What are the two?
First, the section on establishing the termination of life through shared karma; second, the section on establishing the termination of life through individual karma. These are called the two.
In the first gate, there are four kinds.
What are the four?

First, the section on the termination of life of the wind-wheel great earth; second, the section on the termination of life of the water-wheel great earth; third, the section on the termination of life of the gold-wheel great earth; fourth, the section on the termination of life of the fire-wheel great earth. These are called the four.
In this way, these four wheels can encompass all immeasurable and boundless common karmic establishments, the fundamental names and numbers of the categories of severed life.

As for the categories of severed names established by specific karma, it refers to the hair, fur, and other such things in the bodies of sentient beings that are not included in the category of what is appropriated.
In the sÅ«tra on the fundamental causes of karmic practices, it is said:
Furthermore, MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!
As for the world in which sentient beings dwell, there are two kinds.
What are the two?
The first is the general wheel world, and the second is the world of specific support. These are the two.
These two worlds are well able to encompass and support immeasurable and boundless all-dwelling dependent worlds.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Therefore, in the verse it says and immeasurable categories of severed life.
For what reason are all things apart from consciousness called severed life?
It is because they lack the category of discriminating cognition.
Thus far, the various gates of separation from consciousness have been explained. Next, the gate of the existence and non-existence of provisional phenomena will be explained.
Within this gate, there are five kinds.
What are the five?

First, like the moon in water, it provisionally exists; second, like a gandharva city, it provisionally exists; third, like a mirage of water, it provisionally exists; fourth, like an illusory creation, it provisionally exists; fifth, like an echo, it provisionally exists. These are the five.
The MahÄratna-aká¹£ayamatisÅ«tra says:
The five kinds of false analogies such as the moon in water, in total include 55,550 fundamental names of false analogies.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
As a verse says: With equal dust and dust, there is no dharma.
For what reason are all immeasurable false analogies called non-existent?
It is said that because they lack true self-nature, they are called non-existent.
It does not have true reality, but it is not completely non-existent, so it is called existence.
Thus far, the method of revealing the existence of provisional phenomena without true reality has been explained. Next, the method of revealing the absence of things will be discussed.
In this method, there are four kinds.
What are the four?

First, the absence of things like the child of a barren woman; second, the absence of things like the horns of a rabbit or horse; third, the absence of things like the hair of a tortoise; fourth, the absence of things like the defilements of an arhat. These are the four.
In the original sutra, it is said:
Furthermore, Buddha's disciples!

You previously asked, 'What dharmas are called the chapter on non-existence?' The four original explanations such as the child of a barren woman, if I were to explain them extensively, their number would be immeasurable.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Therefore, it is said in the verse, And the inexpressible non-existence.
For what meaning do all empty dharmas all be called non-existent things?
Because there are two kinds.
What are the two?
First, the essence of those empty dharmas is empty, as the four originals say; second, if this emptiness does not explain that, then it is empty, these are called the two.
Thus far, the approach of revealing non-existent things has been explained. Next, the approach of revealing complete unobstruction will be explained.
In this approach, there are ten kinds.
What are the ten?

First, the dharma of the mind's master; second, the dharma of the mind's thoughts; third, the dharma of form's master; fourth, the dharma of form's offspring; fifth, the dharma of non-concordant response; sixth, the dharma of the unconditioned; seventh, the dharma of neither conditioned nor unconditioned; eighth, the dharma of both conditioned and unconditioned; ninth, the dharma of both together; tenth, the dharma of both not together, these are called the ten.
As for the dharma of the mind's master, it refers to the eight consciousnesses and other fundamental dharmas of mind and consciousness.

As for the dharmas of mental concomitants, they are all the enumerated dharmas that correspond to this.ğŸ”½As for the dharmas of primary matter, they are the dharmas that can be made by a single great element.
As for the dharmas of secondary matter, they are the various dharmas of matter that are made by a single great element.
As for the dharmas that are neither matter nor mind, they are the various dharmas that are neither matter nor mind.
As for the unconditioned dharmas, they are the four kinds of unconditioned dharmas such as space.
As for the dharmas that are neither conditioned nor unconditioned, they are the dharmas of the fundamental nature of a single mind, and so forth.

As for the dharmas that are both conditioned and unconditioned, they are the characteristics of the function of the dharmas of the fundamental nature of a single mind, and so forth.ğŸ”½As for the dharmas that are both together, they are the first part of the fundamental dharmas.
As for the dharmas that are not both together, they are the last part of the fundamental dharmas.

In this way, in this gate, one exists and one does not exist, one arises and one ceases, one goes against and one accords, one category and one class are inseparable. Therefore, it is said to manifest the complete unobstructed gate.
In the Mahayana Sutra of the Vast Space of the Most Excellent Virtuous King, it is said:

The number of dust motes in the worlds of the ten directions, which cannot be spoken of, cannot be spoken of, and cannot be spoken of, is the great ocean of Dharma gates, immeasurable and boundless. Each dwelling, each arising, each abiding, each stopping, never divides or abandons.
For this reason, it is established and called the vast, perfect, and complete space, the inexhaustible and limitless Dharma realm of the great ocean gate of each stage.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
As a verse says, it is common to both, and is not equal to all dharmas.

2. The Chapter on the Great Determination of the Conditions for Taking Refuge in the Virtuous Ones, Part 2. The Chapter on the Great Determination of the Conditions for Taking Refuge in the Virtuous Ones, Part 2. Having explained the chapter on the boundless great determination of taking refuge in the virtuous ones, next we will explain the chapter on the great determination of the conditions for taking refuge in the virtuous ones.
What are their characteristics?
A verse says:
There are ten great conditions for creating the ocean of taking refuge in the virtuous ones,
Namely, paying respect, kindness, adding strength, vastness, supremacy, and non-self,
Determination, the great ocean, praising transformation, and manifesting one's own body.
Such ten great conditions are fully possessed by the great being,
The ordinary are not the realm, and even the sages are not able to measure, and the bodhisattvas according to their stage are also unable.
The treatise says:
For what conditions do we take refuge in the virtuous ones?
Because there are ten great conditions, we take refuge.
As a verse says: By having ten kinds of great causes and conditions, one creates the ocean of virtues to which one goes for refuge.
What are called the ten causes and conditions?

First, the cause and condition of profound reverence and respect, able to pay homage and go for refuge to the ocean of virtues, subduing arrogance and increasing wholesome roots, as a verse says: Homage.

Second, the cause and condition of remembering kindness and repaying it, able to create the supreme and wonderful teachings, enlightening all confused beings, and delighting all virtues, as a verse says: Kindness.

Third, the cause and condition of requesting empowerment and accomplishment, if one creates the Dharma gate of the great treatise, if those virtues do not empower it, one cannot discern the ocean of Dharma gates, as a verse says: And empowerment.

Fourth, it is to open up, spread out, and clarify the causes and conditions, using wonderful words to show the clear and bright explanations, manifesting the great ocean of the secret and subtle profound meanings in those sÅ«tras, in order to make them vast, as stated in the verse vast.

Fifth, it is to encourage beings to give rise to the supreme causes and conditions, to compose treatises and teachings to reveal the meanings of the texts, because if one does not take refuge in them, those beings will not be able to ultimately believe, accept, and practice, as stated in the verse supreme.
Sixth, it is the cause and condition of cultivating patience and non-self, giving rise to joy, respect, and reverence, due to the vast mind, as stated in the verse with non-self.

Seventh, the cause and condition of the definite cause of the merit of birth, taking refuge in the place of virtue and creating the teaching of the treatise, whether seeing, hearing, seeing the seer, hearing the hearer, or living in the same country, all of them at all times do not move, giving birth to and increasing immeasurable and boundless all kinds of merit and the category of wholesome roots, definitely and definitely not mistaken or contrary, as the verse says definite therefore.

Eighth, the cause and condition of the inexhaustible treasure of the great ocean, accumulating immeasurable and boundless all kinds of powers, creating the supreme and perfect great ocean wish-fulfilling jewel wheel and the vajra treasury of virtue, in order to save and deliver immeasurable and boundless poor and suffering sentient beings, as the verse says great ocean therefore.

Ninth, the cause and condition of skillfully teaching and transforming, although there is no separate refuge in the category of completeness, it praises teaching and transforming in order to benefit sentient beings, as the verse says and praises transformation therefore.

Tenth, manifesting the causes and conditions of one's past body, because all the places of virtue to which one returns are none other than one's own body's embrace, as a verse says, Also manifesting one's own body.
These are called the ten kinds of great causes and conditions.
Who creates such vast and excellent causes and conditions?
Buddhas and bodhisattvas create them.
Even bodhisattvas cannot create them, let alone ordinary people or the two vehicles.

As a verse says, Only a perfect great being can possess these ten kinds of great causes and conditions. They are not the realm of ordinary people, nor the measure of sages. Even bodhisattvas with partial attainments cannot do so.
